newsitem.title: UK: UK chemical industry calls for EMU delay.
newsitem.headline: UK chemical industry calls for EMU delay.

text.p: Britain's chemical industry called on Wednesday for the introduction of any single European currency to be delayed, but said Britain must be involved from the start if it goes ahead.

In a speech to the Chemical Industries Association (CIA) annual investor intentions conference, CIA director general Elliot Finer said there was a danger that the Maastricht criteria for European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) would be fudged.

"We would not want EMU to go ahead before it was clear that economic conditions in member countries were sufficiently convergent and policies and markets were sufficiently flexible and responsive to local conditions," said Finer.
But he repeated the CIA's view that Britain should join from the start. The association believes that membership would save 200 million stg a year in transaction costs.
Finer also said a core group of members "would inevitably become a more attractive place for investment at the expense of the UK".

He told the conference that uncertainty about UK membership of a single currency may be one factor depressing investment plans by the British industry, which he said remained at a low level for the fourth year in a row in 1996.
Finer said that last year's capital investment total of 2.15 billion stg was around 23 percent below the 1989 peak.
